citations.narrative:
An enclosure housing two adult emus does not provide adequate access to shelter from inclement weather. The two
artificial shelter structures in the enclosure are not tall enough to allow easy access due to the short/narrow entrances.
The entrances to the shelter structures are approximately half as tall as the animals that are housed in the enclosure.
Failure to provide adequate shelter from inclimate weather to avian species can result in negative impacts to the health of
the birds due to exposure. Outdoor housing facilities must provide adequate shelter, appropriate to the species and
physical condition of the birds, for the local climatic conditions to protect the birds from any adverse weather conditions.
Correct by, 17-January-2025.

An enclosure housing two adult emus has exposed sharp wire points along the top of the primary enclosure chain link
fencing. The upper edge of the wire chain link fence has barbs where the wire was cut, and the ends are twisted together
creating many sharp points in the enclosure. Failure to ensure that no sharp points are present in enclosures housing
birds can result in injuries to the birds. Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that
they are structurally sound. Correct by ensuring that all primary enclosures are kept in good repair and are free of sharp
points or edges that could injure birds. Correct by, 17-January-2025.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The licensee was unable to provide a written environmental enhancement plan for the two Emu, 8 peacock, and 12
pigeons held at the facility. A written plan is necessary to ensure that the overall health, well-being, and psychological
needs of the birds are being appropriately met. Failure to follow a species-appropriate environmental enhancement plan
can lead to psychological distress and abnormal behaviors in birds housed at the facility. Facilities that house avian
species must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to
promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be in accordance with the currently accepted professional
standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides and be approved by the attending veterinarian.
The plan must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and
exemptions. The environmental enhancement plan must be made available to APHIS officials upon request. Correct by,
17-January-2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Facility Representative.
n

narrative:
3.152(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor 
An enclosure housing two adult emus does not provide adequate access to shelter from inclement weather. The two 
artificial shelter structures in the enclosure are not tall enough to allow easy access due to the short/narrow entrances. 
The entrances to the shelter structures are approximately half as tall as the animals that are housed in the enclosure.  
Failure to provide adequate shelter from inclimate weather to avian species can result in negative impacts to the health of 
the birds due to exposure. Outdoor housing facilities must provide adequate shelter, appropriate to the species and 
physical condition of the birds, for the local climatic conditions to protect the birds from any adverse weather conditions. 
Correct by, 17-January-2025. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
An enclosure housing two adult emus has exposed sharp wire points along the top of the primary enclosure chain link 
fencing. The upper edge of the wire chain link fence has barbs where the wire was cut, and the ends are twisted together 
creating many sharp points in the enclosure. Failure to ensure that no sharp points are present in enclosures housing 
birds can result in injuries to the birds. Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that 
they are structurally sound. Correct by ensuring that all primary enclosures are kept in good repair and are free of sharp 
points or edges that could injure birds. Correct by, 17-January-2025. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The licensee was unable to provide a written environmental enhancement plan for the two Emu, 8 peacock, and 12 
pigeons held at the facility. A written plan is necessary to ensure that the overall health, well-being, and psychological 
needs of the birds are being appropriately met. Failure to follow a species-appropriate environmental enhancement plan 
can lead to psychological distress and abnormal behaviors in birds housed at the facility. Facilities that house avian 
species must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to 
promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be in accordance with the currently accepted professional 
standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides and be approved by the attending veterinarian. 
The plan must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and 
exemptions. The environmental enhancement plan must be made available to APHIS officials upon request. Correct by, 
17-January-2025.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Facility Representative.
